characters: YOU ARE NOTHING. I PROMISE YOU --
BETTER KILL ME NOW BECAUSE YOU WILL NOT GET
I NEED TO FIND THAT AUSSIE BASTARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The glare doesn’t bother Garrison. He rides in the back o dilapidated truck -- alive and well -- for now. Despite his every-man demeanor and rugged good-looks, Garrison's clear eyes betray a sharp intellect... a guy’s who knows how to get the job done. A F.A.R.C. GUERRILLA sits across from him, AK-47 pointed right at Garrison. The truck hits a bump -- and another - the guerrilla’s finger rests tentatively on the trigger..

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: (Spanish, subtitled) Mind pointing that somewhere else? Rather not die by pot-hole. The guard doesn’t flinch. Garrison laughs it off as the t pulls into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three dozen COMMUNIST REVOLUTIONARIES get to their feet. GUARDS hang back, watching over a bound HOSTAGE. Garrison notices. Gives the trio (hostage+guards) a wave. Note: dialogue in italics is subtitled.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Love how you guys settle domestic disputes here. Old school.  From the truck a CRATE emerges. Garrison pops the lid, revealing: cases of 9mm shells. GARRISON (CONT’D) Ahead of the R&D curve here with depleted uranium rounds. Melt anything they touch: metal, kevlar, capitalism. The guerrilla LEADER examines the bullets.

dialogues.speaker: LEADER
dialogues.text: How much for the crate?

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: A gift. Viva la revolucién!

dialogues.speaker: REBELS
dialogues.text: Viva la revolucién! Garrison's playing to the crowd -- and they’re loving it. except a particularly UGLY guerrilla.

dialogues.speaker: LEADER
dialogues.text: And the next crate?

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Is not a gift. Both men smile. Capitalism is doing just fine. Soldiers descend on the crate like wolves, loading their weapons w the next gen ammunition. POP OUT TO: SNIPER POV of Garrison and the guerrilla lead

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Kill Team Two, eyes on target.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR THE HOSTAGE
dialogues.text: The guards watch their brothers hoard the ammo. Pretty so it will all be gone. Garrison wanders over, offers some friendly advice:

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Better get it while you can... Don’t have to tell them twice. The guards quickly join th throng, fighting for their share of the ammo. After a bea Garrison discretely CUTS THE ROPES tying the Hostage down GARRISON (CONT’D) (harsh whisper) Stay close to me and -- wait.  In a pure panic, the American RUNS for the woods ahead. Garrison starts after him as he barks into his comm unit: GARRISON (CONT’D) Get ready to go loud. The guerrilla leader is loading his rifle when he sees: his prize hostage running into the brush.

dialogues.speaker: LEADER
dialogues.text: The American -- he's escaping! The leader's body suddenly LURCHES to the ground, hit by sniper round. And then a SECOND REBEL is kicked to the ground by anothe CRACK of a shot. Unseen sniper teams unload on the rebels Guerrillas return but their weapons lock up. One REBEL behind cover ejects his magazine and yanks out round of ammo to discover:

dialogues.speaker: OBSERVANT REBEL
dialogues.text: No blasting caps! Don't use the ammo -- BACK TO: Garrison, in pursuit of the Hostage -- Then he sees that ugly rebel RUN down the --

dialogues.speaker: MOUNTAINSIDE
dialogues.text: The hostage SPRINTS through the brush -- terrified -- loo back and sees -- that ugly rebel -- closing in -- bowie k in hand. The hostage panics -- STUMBLES into a ravine -- can’t esc - no choice but to hide. Ugly slides into the ravine... searching for the hidden hostage. Getting closer... 10 feet... 5 feet... right as about to discover the hostage --

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Viva la revolucién! It’s Garrison, running towards him. Ugly readies his blad Ugly LUNGES -- but in one swift motion Garrison SIDE-STEP GRABS Ugly’s wrist -- FLIPS the knife -- and DRIVES it in Ugly’s belly -- dropping him next to the hostage -- dead.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Mr. Sachs, I’m with the Navy Seal hostage rescue team -- we’re here to take you home. SACHS is clearly in shock, scared even of Garrison -- da torture make everyone seem predatory -- GUNFIRE and SHOUTS from the camp -- in a few seconds it w be too much for Garrison to fight.

dialogues.speaker: SNIPER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Position is compromised. Sir -- Yet Garrison pulls out a SMARTPHONE and shows it to Sachs

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Hey. Hey. Look at this. Your family is waiting for you. Back home. A beautiful, teary-eyed WIFE and six-year-old SON talk in the phone’s camera, their tinny voices just beyond earsho for us, but Sachs hears them. His eyes focus. He holds the phone, staring at them. We d catch a little bit from the recording:

dialogues.speaker: BOY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Come home, Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: SNIPER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (in Garrison’s comm) You need to move now, lieutenant! But Garrison puts a gentle hand on Sachs’ shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Let’s get you back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OSPREY HELICOPTER hovers as Garrison emerges from the brush with the hostage. Sniper teams cover them as Garris clips in -- winch pulling them to safety. Off the rescued hostage’s relieved face -- CUT TO: The SON’s face. Watching as a C-17 CARGO PLANE touches do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane comes to a halt. Bay doors open... and Garrison team steps out. Families are waiting in the parking lot. Wives welcome their men back. Children run into their fathers’ arms. Sachs is reunited with his family. But there’s no one there to meet Garrison. He jokes with teammates, exchanging good-byes as he walks off alone. Suddenly a ‘66 Chevy pick-up SCREECHES to a stop -- driv side door WHIPS open as GINA GARRISON, 20s, jumps out -- tackles Garrison in her embrace. As they smile and smooch

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: You’re late.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: You're early. You know that thing each couple has? That's theirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chevy RACES down the highway, water glistening on bot sides of the road... almost too beautiful to be real. Gin drives. Garrison listens to the engine, watches her.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: When you gonna let me buy you a truck born in this century?

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: When this beauty finally dies on me. Until then, I’m a loyal girl.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: At least let me drive us to TJ.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Because it’s so much like Florence.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: (playing along) Florence has the Duomo, TJ has the donkey show.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: We had our honeymoon in Mexico... so, it’s not that bad.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: But it’s not your dream. We'll have a big getaway soon... I promise.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: Not with your job, no sir.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: I‘1l make time for it. Once you get pregnant --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready to be the stay-at-home dad? She grins at him, playful. Garrison grins back.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: I’‘1l have to retire early, then. Or is that your whole plan?

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: I’m a proud supporter of any plan that keeps you close to home. Until then, lieutenant, we'll just have to practice making babies -- a lot. He kisses her on the neck as they ROAR towards the border She's trying to keep one eye on the road, but damn does h a good job of distracting her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Day of the Dead celebration is in full effect. Brightly colored paper maché skeletons. Coffins over-flowing with carnations. Children in skull face paint. A FIRE-BREATHER shoots a stream of flames into the night

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orange fire-light glows outside the window to this ho room, where Gina turns down the sheets. Drifting into the --

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Garrison stands in front of the mirror, shirtless. His ch is a roadmap of old scars. He’s inspecting a potential ne one; some scrape he got in Colombia. Gina enters, snakes her arms around him.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Yeah, just grazed my pride is all. Maybe I’m losing my touch.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: Oh, you got plenty of moves, husband. She grapples him around the waist and neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me how you get out of this one. Garrison smiles -- this is their foreplay.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Well, you step into their space --

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: Oh I like that -- He plants a foot between hers, puts his hands on her arms

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Then you just twist, and -- In a slow spin, he’s twirled her around and grappled her similar fashion. Gina distracts him with a kiss, and as he starts to get l in that sensuality -- She tips him off-balance and then yanks him out of the bathroom door, tossing him onto --

dialogues.speaker: THE BED
dialogues.text: -- where she descends on him, only to be partially pinned Garrison pulls at her cotton top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The celebration is louder now; more crowded and full of music. There’s something chaotic and intense about the en in the streets. A manic parade.

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE
dialogues.text: Just as intense, but full of a different energy -- passio Ray and Gina make love. Their skin glistens with sweat... they’re not done. Not yet. The festival builds as their bodies collide until --

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The pre-dawn light shines through the window. The street below is quiet. They lie in each others arms... somewhere between awake and dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: Who do you think our kid would look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She better look like you. ‘Cause me in a dress ain’t pretty.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: She?

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: It's less surprising that I’ve worn a dress than I said “she?”

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: You do like to work undercover... Garrison pulls the sheets up as Gina giggles.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: I do my best work under cover...

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: I’m serious --

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: I don’t know... just always assumed I'd have a little girl. Teach her to play guitar... to stand up for herself... walk her down the aisle... Gina traces her fingers over his Navy Seal tattoo.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: I feel sorry for the boy who shows up for that first date...

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: If he shows up, he’ll be the bravest kid in school.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: Or the dumbest. (hopeful) If you really want to be a father... Garrison is torn, but the truth comes out:

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: I got a few more years of the work in me. Gina’s smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: I know. I’m not pushing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just can’t be both. Meaning both a SEAL and a father.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: Yeah... (then) Besides, I think I love tequila too much to quit anytime soon. They cuddle close again, but now they both stare off in different directions, each preoccupied with a what-if...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The remnants of the festival litter the street. Scattered paper maché skulls stare back... smiling faces of death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garrison WAKES with a start. He rolls over to find... nothing. No one. Gina’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Gina...? No response. He gets up. Searches the room... until he fi a note, scrawled on the back of a receipt. Went to get us breakfast, back soon. Practice makes perfe Garrison breathes a sigh of relief. Sits for a moment. Lo in his own thoughts... GARRISON (V.O., PRE-LAP) (CONT’D) Sorry to call so early. Just needed to talk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garrison’s on the balcony, leaving a voicemail.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Thinking about getting out of the field, taking that instructor’s post. Anyway... give me a shout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garrison’s in the shower, hears Gina return.  10.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: You’re late! (beat) Hey -- I said, “You’re late!” Garrison peeks out of the shower curtain -- GARRISON (CONT’D) “You're early?” He spots someone in the mirror-- and it ain’t Gina. Two men in street clothes clear the room like PROS. Move the bathroom, aim M7 Trang pistols at the shower -- DARTS perforate the curtain. Then -- nothing. PRO ONE covers Pro Two as he steps into the bathroom... shower BLASTING... reaches out... WHIPS the curtain back finds -- nothing. Huh? Suddenly he’s PUNCHED in the junk by Garrison, huddled on floor of the tub taking cover. Pro Two crumbles -- Garrison GRABS his shirt -- SLAMS his face into the tub -- HARD. Pro One fires -- Garrison uses Two's body as a shield -- takes his weapon and returns. They empty their clips. Pro One reloads -- Garrison doesn hesitate -- RIPS down the shower curtain and CHARGES -- Garrison attacks -- soaking wet and completely naked. Lightning-fast, hand-to-hand. Garrison uses the shower curtain to deflect blows and disorient -- Pro One LUNGES at Garrison -- who quickly sidesteps so th Pro One inadvertently CRASHES through the window and onto balcony, buying Garrison enough time to SPRINT into the -

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Where he accidentally SLAMS into a stunned AUSSIE tourist more than a little shocked by the butt-naked Garrison.

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE
dialogues.text: Think you forgot a few things, friend. The aussie tourist tries to help Garrison to his feet -- then STABS Garrison with an auto injector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shocked Garrison tries to run... but his legs lock-up.. his vision... cloudy... finally he collapses as we -- CUT  11.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKNESS
dialogues.text: Then... Led Zeppelin, Stairway to Heaven. Guitar RIPPING. Blackness becomes blinding white light as a hood comes of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garrison opens his eyes... can’t adjust to the glare. The music. It’s overwhelming.

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE
dialogues.text: Back from the dead. Garrison tries to get his bearings... in some kind of:

dialogues.speaker: BARN
dialogues.text: Can’t see much... interrogation light is intense... music grating. In front of him is that aussie tourist.

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE
dialogues.text: Zeppelin, absolute genius.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Who...

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE
dialogues.text: Led Zeppelin. Jimmy Page, Robert --

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: «.-are you?

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE
dialogues.text: I’m the guy who ruined your vacation. Garrison’s color is coming back -- confidence returning.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Well, I’m the guy who makes less than a public school teacher, so if you’re looking for a ransom --

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t need money.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Then... what?

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE
dialogues.text: Information. About your missions in Colombia? Shit. This isn’t just some Mexican ransom play...  12.

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See, friend, I make a very good living selling weapons to the FARC guerrillas. But when there’s instability in the FARC, there’s instability in my business.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Well, your business ain’t getting any more stable, ‘cause all you’re getting out of me is name, rank, and a hearty helping of go- fuck-yourself.

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE
dialogues.text: Oh, but we’re serving something much tastier tonight... Aussie gives the cue and his GUYS drag in Gina. Bound and gagged, she’s scared out of her mind. Garrison goes white

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Those brass balls just got a whole lot softer.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: I’m about to tell you the God’s honest truth: I’m a professional, like you. All I care about is getting the job done and going home. I don’t know where the intel comes from and I don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE
dialogues.text: Bet you care now? Aussie RIPS the tape off Gina’s mouth, sticks his .45 in.

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s it, Flower, take it all... He PUSHES the barrel deep into her throat. Gina GAGS -- h face, pure terror. Garrison tries to get Aussie’s attenti

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Look at me -- LOOK AT ME. Aussie does. Something about Garrison's voice -- like thi the most important moment of his life. GARRISON (CONT’D) If I knew, I’d tell you. Ask me anything else, anything you want to know. But this I can’t tell you. Because I don’t know. Aussie and Garrison hold each other’s gaze... Finally --  13.

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE
dialogues.text: I believe you. He takes his gun out of Gina’s mouth. She GASPS... tears streaming down her face.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: It’s gonna be okay, baby -- I promise. She smiles -- believes him -- loves him with all her hear Aussie casually turns off the music.

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE
dialogues.text: Well, this has been a colossal waste of time. And SHOOTS Gina in the head. The world slows down... the blast knocking Gina over in h chair... Garrison watches as her eyes go cold... dead bef she even hits the ground. Suddenly time SNAPS back and -- Garrison explodes -- snot and spit -- doesn’t give a fuck

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: YOU ARE NOTHING. YOU DON’T EXIST ANYMORE.I

dialogues.speaker: A SECOND CHANCE.
dialogues.text: Aussie points his .45 right at Garrison and --

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE
dialogues.text: Thanks for the advice.

dialogues.speaker: GUNSHOT
dialogues.text: BLACK. Then...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (Cantonese, subtitled) Project Bloodshot procedure log...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garrison's corpse. In a black abyss. A red light begins to BLINK... illuminating the rest of Garrison’s dead body. Nothing more than a husk, a vessel vengeance and violence. So that’s what we’ll call him: BLOODSHOT.  14. Turns out he’s not in a casket, but some kind of high tec sensory deprivation tank. A circular needle array PUMPS b fluid into his chest. Note: Dialogue in italics is subtit

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Transfusion complete. The circular needle array retracts from his chest.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Commence bioelectrical charge. That’s when we hear it... a beat... building in our ears.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fifty percent... Soon the beat becomes a song... a song we recognize...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seventy-five percent... “Stairway to Heaven” by Led Zeppelin. What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Full cycle. An electrical charge RIPS through Bloodshot’s corpse -- h body SPASMS -- and then stops... lying there motionless.. until his eyes flutter open. He’s alive.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Subject is conscious. BP one forty over ninety. Heart Rate seventy-five. Brain function normal. Bloodshot tries to move, but can’t -- limbs locked in pla

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Where...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Language centers online.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: ---am I?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (in English) Identify yourself. Bloodshot is beyond confused. What the hell is going on?  15.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take your time. Think. What is your name? That’s when Bloodshot starts to panic. And it’s not becau he’s scared, it’s because--

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: I don’t know... Bloodshot thrashes violently, emotions overwhelming him.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Initiate sedation.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: WHY DON’T I KNOW?!?

dialogues.speaker: BLACKNESS
dialogues.text: The music kicks in again. Skipping like a record as it dr that grating vocal into our brains. As we wind on down the -- As we wind on down the As we wind on down the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot wakes with a start. Looks around. He’s in a:

dialogues.speaker: RECOVERY ROOM
dialogues.text: Sterile. White. Looks like your average hospital room. Th music has stopped. Bloodshot sits up. He’s wearing a hospital gown -- nothin else. His skin is pale. His head -- pounding. Seems to be fine except... his sternum aches. Pulls the gown off his shoulders revealing... A circular red scar in the middle of his white chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and in walks DR. EMIL HARTING, 40s. Built a rugby player, the first thing we notices is that there’ something odd about his arm... robotic.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: (British accent) How are you feeling? Bloodshot rubs his temples...

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Hell of a hangover.  16.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Then you remember -- what a hangover feels like? Harting’s trying to act normal but he’s clearly on edge.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, yes.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: That’s good.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Says you. Speaking of --

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Dr. Emil Harting, Rising Spirit Technologies.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: (re: his lack of memory) I'd return the courtesy but I’ve got this little problem...

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Unfortunately I’m not going to be much help. This is what we have on you. Harting retrieves a SLIM FILE for Bloodshot, who looks in to find a brief PROFILE of who he once was: Lieutenant Raymond Garrison, U.S. Navy SEAL. The page is labeled TOP SECRET, and the bit at the bottom is why: “Cadaver sold to Rising Spirit Technologies.”

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your remains were sold to us by the US military. All personnel records, destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: (in total shock) My... remains?

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: We brought you back. That’s when Harting smiles, barely containing his excitem

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We've been experimenting with nanites -- robotic proteins. They can rebuild otherwise healthy tissues on a cellular level after catastrophic injury.  17. Harting touches the wall... it becomes a view screen. ON THE MONITOR: Images of those alien machines from the opening... working furiously.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We had so much success with individual organ systems that we decided to try a full transfusion. Your blood was replaced with the nanites... and they repaired everything. Even your oxygen-starved brain. Harting looks almost as shocked as Garrison.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: I’m... an experiment?

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Based on animal trials we expected -- optimum outcome -- that you’d be in a vegetative state. But here you are.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: My memories, they’re gone...

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Our best guess? The nanites revitalized the brain tissues but couldn’t recreate past experiences. To put it simply, we saved the hard drive but lost the data.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: But I remember how to walk. How to talk. I know that seven times seven is forty nine and that the capital of New York is Albany.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: You also know the square root of seven thousand nine hundred and twenty one... ENDOSCOPIC SHOT: Bloodshot’s brain -- a nanite builds a synapse -- FLASH ON: thousands of numbers, speeding by -- land on --

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Eighty nine.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: The word for father in, I don’t know, Swahili. ENDOSCOPIC SHOT: Bloodshot’s brain -- nanites create anot synapse --  18. FLASH ON: Swahili translations for, “Fate,” “Fateful,” th

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Father... “Abu.”

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: And the winner of the Tour de France in, say, 1909 --

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Francois Faber. How do I know that?

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: There are billions of web-enabled microprocessors inside your brain. Any information they don’t already know, they can pull that data from the ‘net.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Can they tell me who I am? Figure out what happened to me?

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Let me show you something... Harting takes off his lab coat, revealing a gleaming prosthetic arm connected to his twitching shoulder muscle

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As a kid, I was a tennis prodigy. Good but not great -- no serve. On my fifteenth birthday I got Cancer. Six months later they took my arm. Instead of focusing on what I had lost, I focused on what I had been given... an opportunity to do something else with my life. PhD from MIT by twenty-two, my first military contract by twenty-four, and my own firm -- Rising Spirit Technologies -- by thirty. One day soon, when a soldier loses his arm... Harting raises his cybernetic fist and SLAMS it into the metal table -- leaving a massive dent.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-he’s going to get a better one. Because I forgot who I was and focused on who I could become.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: (catching on) Rising Spirit... bet you got a hell of a serve now?  19. Harting smiles. Clearly these two are going to become brothers... both given a second chance by technology.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Let’s see what you can do now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: State of the art testing center. Bloodshot is caged in a giant water wheel: the human equivalent of a hamster whee except this one is dipped in a pool, requiring Bloodshot strain his muscles to power the mill wheel. Setup nearby: EKG, mobile CT, and a pulse ox monitor.

dialogues.speaker: TECH
dialogues.text: Eight miles per hour, at a water resistance of seventy-five pounds. Harting and a handful of TECHS watch as Bloodshot STRAINS and moves the giant wheel under his own power.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Push him to ten. ENDOSCOPIC SHOT: Bloodshot’s lungs -- nanites work to EXP his alveoli so that -- Bloodshot BREATHES deeper -- his lungs working more efficiently, allowing him to -- Crest past ten MPH on the monitor. All the while the pool CHURNS from the turning of the wheel. Fighting Bloodshot every step.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: But I had a life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot follows Harting on a tour of the facility. Hart is now dressed in a custom lab coat -- the lack of collar colorful trim make it seem vaguely Asian. Bloodshot looks down at the Navy Seal tattoo on his arm.. BLOODSHOT (CONT’D) ...there must’ve been people I loved... I cared about.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: They said their good-byes. You need to do the same. We’re on a new frontier here...  20. They pass above an indoor track. Techs observe a VET jogg on hydrogen powered prosthetic legs...

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are no guarantees with this process... tomorrow you could be gone. For good. Do you really want to risk putting them through that again? The vet begins to SPRINT -- faster than Usain Bolt. Blood can hardly believe his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: What is this place?

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Hope. For every warrior wounded on a battlefield. And for soldiers like you.

dialogues.speaker: RISING SPIRIT
dialogues.text: - A TEST PILOT in a hydraulic skeleton LIFTS steel plates

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In this facility alone, we’re developing everything from exoskeletons that can help aman lift ten-times his weight... - A PATIENT with a prosthetic leg re-learns how to swim i Olympic-sized POOL with help from a TRAINER.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...to smart prosthetic limbs so the critically injured can live normal lives... - A RESEARCH SCIENTIST presents a paper on cybernetic eye

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-even ocular implants that will allow the blind to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harting and Bloodshot finish their tour on the top floor Rising Spirit’s skyscraper. The Hong Kong skyline glimmer around them... it's breath-taking -- and entirely man-mad

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: We're on the precipice of a paradigm shift... and you’re the proof.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: But am I really alive? It’s been, what, twenty-four hours...  21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot has his arm under a scanning electron microscop BLOODSHOT (CONT’D) --.and I’m not the least bit tired. Harting looks through the eye-piece at Bloodshot’s skin cells. The monitor behind him displays the image.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: From the day we stop growing, our bodies begin dying. Our skin cells wither away, our muscles are cannibalized, and our bones degrade. Harting reaches for a scalpel...

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But not you. The nanites are constantly repairing your body on a cellular level.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: So I'll never have to exfoliate again?

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: It’s a little more exciting than that... FLASH of the scalpel -- Harting SLICES Bloodshot’s hand - recoils -- but Harting pins his wrist under the microscop ON THE SCREEN: The magnified nanites pour out of the woun and stitch the skin back together... one cell at a time. Holy shit. Harting releases him. Bloodshot stares at his as the cut disappears before our eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s exciting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New, day -- same water wheel. Display reads: 20 mph... 21 Bloodshot is soaked in sweat, right at the point of break

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Okay. That’s enough.

dialogues.speaker: LAB TECH
dialogues.text: The record at this resistance level is twenty-five miles per hour... ENDOSCOPIC SHOT: Bloodshot’s quads -- with each stride, muscles tear -- but are instantly repaired by the nanites  22.

dialogues.speaker: SOMEBODY PLAY THE ROCKY THEME.
dialogues.text: Pure determination -- this guy is not going to stop until reaches his goal. ON THE READOUT: 23... 24... The water carried by the wheel’s pockets CHURN and FROTH spray the back of the fitness lab like a rooster tail... And then something CRACKS at 25 MPH. The axle wobbles. An Bloodshot nearly rolls the thing out the pool. He hits against the inside and spins like a stray piece of clothi in an enormous dryer, and then... Collapses.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: The turbine -- it cracked. Bloodshot can’t help but smile. He broke the thing.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Better get a new one.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Thanks for the advice. Bloodshot’s head snaps up --

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Thanks for the advice. (beat) Why? Bloodshot’s heart rate picks up... POUNDING in our ears..

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Nothing. Harting holds his gaze... something's definitely wrong. Bloodshot grabs a water. That’s when we hear it... music. BLOODSHOT (CONT’D) You hear that?

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Hear what? It's Stairway to Heaven. Bloodshot sits -- head in his ha Music won’t stop -- like a hammer, SLAMMING into his brai A TEST PILOT enters --  23.

dialogues.speaker: TEST PILOT
dialogues.text: Got this room booked.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE TECH
dialogues.text: In fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: TEST PILOT
dialogues.text: You’re late.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE TECH
dialogues.text: You're early. FLASH ON: Gina -- smiling in the Chevy --

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: You're early. BACK TO: Bloodshot -- doubles over in pain --

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? FLASHBACK TO: Gina dead on the ground. Garrison foaming -

dialogues.speaker: YOU ARE NOTHING. I PROMISE YOU --
dialogues.text: BACK TO: Bloodshot -- teeth GRINDING -- heart POUNDING --

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: --I-will-find-you-and-end-you-- Harting panics -- turns to the tech --

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Get medical in here -- NOW. Harting GRABS Bloodshot -- helps him to a chair -- Zeppel track builds -- BLASTING in our ears -- sensory overload

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: --you-better-kill-me-now--

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Breathe. Try to Breathe --

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: --you-will-not-get-a-second-chance. FLASH ON: Aussie standing over us, .45 pointed at the len

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE
dialogues.text: Thanks for the advice.  24. GUNSHOT RIPS US BACK TO: Bloodshot -- SLAMMING Harting against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: He killed me -- my wife. His face -- I can see it.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Seal the room! Door starts to close -- Bloodshot STOPS it -- ESCAPES int the corridor -- Harting PULLS the ALARM --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sirens BLARE -- Bloodshot SPRINTS -- a wounded animal, doesn’t know where he’s going, doesn’t care -- heart raci turns the corner, sees: SECURITY -- a dozen men in high tech SWAT GEAR with TASER BATONS. Bloodshot doubles back -- off his face -- FLASH ON: Gina in bed, naked. Day of the dead images from Mexico -- coffins and carnations, child in skull face pai BACK TO: Bloodshot -- heart POUNDING -- legs failing -- Security -- coming at us -- COMMANDER takes point. Bloods LUNGES for a fire extinguisher -- BREAKS the glass --

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Didn't save her... my fault... Taser batons CRACKLE to life, guards close in. Bloodshot THROWS the extinguisher at them, misses by a mile -- -- but hits his intended target: A SPRINKLER HEAD. Hallwa fills with that fire retardant HAZE, visibility zero.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER
dialogues.text: Get that fire suppression system off, NOW. Guard PULLS the emergency shut-off. The haze clears and t soldiers find... nothing. Commander spots an emergency exit door ajar...

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER, (INTO COM)
dialogues.text: Entered south stairwell, sub-level five.  25.

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE
dialogues.text: Harting and a handful of TECHS monitor the situation from center of Rising Spirit’s security grid.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (INTO COM)
dialogues.text: Chainsaw -- headed your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot staggers up the stairs -- heart POUNDING -- FLA ON Gina’s tear-stained face -- Aussie’s smug smile, his . pointed right at us --

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE
dialogues.text: Thanks for the advice. GUNSHOT echoes from the past -- One more flight of stairs -- ground level. Taser baton in hand, Bloodshot enters the --

dialogues.speaker: GROUND FLOOR
dialogues.text: That’s when he hears it... the metallic CLANG of footstep Bloodshot looks up and sees -- A massive man wearing a skull-shaped ballistic face mask, words “SO LONG” spray painted on his chest plate. SO LONG steps forward on hydrogen powered prosthetic legs These things look more like sleek, articulated plastic li not like bulky metal armor. The legs, in combination with a spinal support, allow him lift a cannon, firing a tsunami of SOUND WAVES -- SLAMMIN Bloodshot against the wall -- HARD. He tries to crawl away -- his nanites working hard to hea A WOMAN in tactical armor cuts him off -- THROWS somethin

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Catch. Bloodshot tries to duck -- too late -- the object EXPLODE sarin gas BURNING his eyes and lungs. A blinded Bloodshot HOWLS in pain. So Long GRABS him by t neck -- lifts Bloodshot up to eye-level...

dialogues.speaker: SO LONG
dialogues.text: Bet that hurt...  26. Bloodshot looks up at So Long --

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Bet this hurts more. The taser baton in Bloodshot’s hand CRACKLES to life -- t a cheap shot -- JAMS it under SO LONG’s face mask. So Long BELLOWS in pain -- drops Bloodshot -- who SCURRIE towards the door and freedom. The woman in the tactical armor gives chase as we POP OUT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SNIPER POV of the ground floor. No windows -- just a wall SNIPER’S VOICE (0.C.) Chainsaw Bravo, stand down -- Alpha has target. ECU of the sniper’s eye reveals an ocular implant -- it F from grey to red, allowing the sniper to see Bloodshot’s signature through the wall. He squeezes the trigger -- BULLET POV: ROCKET out the barrel and BLAST through the w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time slows down as the bullet erupts from the wall -- red speed -- and extends a TRANQ DART, SLAMMING into an escap Bloodshot’s neck -- LIGHTS OUT. CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: We're talking about a multibillion dollar contract --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice belongs to RST’s Chairman, MORRIS KOZOL, 50s, skyping with Harting. The conference room is decorated in Feudal Japan. Bonsai. Woodcut art. Swords on walls.

dialogues.speaker: KOZOL
dialogues.text: Bottom line it: how much more time do you need? Do I need to buy you some more dead soldiers? At this rate I’1l have to start another war for you.  27. Harting seethes... he does not like to be pinned down.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: He’s revived but he still has all the baggage of a person with his experience. It's delicate work. Let me do my job.

dialogues.speaker: KOZOL
dialogues.text: My job, Doctor, is to remind you that he’s not a person, he’s property. And you don’t have a good track record when it comes to securing our property. We can’t let Harada get ahead of us on this.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: We're handling that. Nearly finished.

dialogues.speaker: KOZOL
dialogues.text: Finish your job so I can do mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot slowly comes to -- on a hospital bed. Tied down

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Harting please... I have to find him... I just let her die... No response. He’s all alone. Trapped. Then -- the door op and in walks Harting. He approaches the restrained Bloods

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: We need each other.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: How do you know he’s Australian?

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: He just shot her... FLICKER THROUGH dozens of images: the mission in Colombia Day of the Dead festival in Mexico, Aussie smiling as he his .45 down Gina’s throat... Bloodshot remembers everything we’ve seen so far.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can see his face -- like it just happened. But that’s it -- nothing else. Not my name, not his, nothing... only her... my wife, Gina.  28. Last image is of Gina in the Chevy as they race toward th border, sun flaring off the water... it’s so beautiful it breaks your heart. BACK TO:

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Why do I remember those two days and nothing else? Not my parents -- not my childhood -- not even my own name.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Honestly... I don’t know. Maybe because those last few days were so significant that they’re seared into your mind? Like muscle memory.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: I have to find him... have to make him pay for Gina. She’s the one thing I know I loved in this world, and that one thing is gone. All that’s left is... anger.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Listen to me, you need time here to train. And I need time to study you. Bloodshot is torn... drowning in guilt.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Have you ever lost someone that meant everything to you? Harting opens up to Bloodshot, looking him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: More than once. Every time, I thought I’d never recover. Never get attached again. (breath) That’s the triumph of the human spirit, I guess. You get up and try again.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: I can’t do that until he’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: You are a prototype. One of a kind. In the world of science, that’s useless. We need to find a way to reproduce your results if we're going to save lives. This isn’t about you. It’s about soldiers who could return home to their loved ones... Bloodshot considers Harting’s words...  29.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do this for me, and I’1l use every resource at my disposal to help you find this man.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: And end him.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: You have my word. Harting touches the control screen. Restraints retract and Bloodshot falls to his knees. As Harting helps him to his feet...

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: One more thing: after I kill him... he stays dead. Bloodshot walks past, for the door, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A helicopter ROARS out of the city...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harting’s at the helm, Bloodshot sitting next to him.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (INTO COM)
dialogues.text: Every human has deep-rooted survival instincts. You have to unlearn them.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT, (INTO COM)
dialogues.text: Unlearn --? They’re called ‘survival instincts’ for a good reason, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (INTO COM)
dialogues.text: They don’t apply to you now. The goal posts have moved. The nanites in your body can do more than simply heal a wound. They are tools to let you adapt. Modify. Overcome. You simply command them to do your bidding.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT, (INTO COM)
dialogues.text: Will this be painful? Sounds painful --

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: (interrupting) My field test team “Chainsaw” is going to put you in the most stressful situations possible -- push you until you learn to change your body in response.  30.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: “Chainsaw?”

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Cut down every prototype I throw at them. Harting smiles as the helicopter SOARS over the mountains revealing --

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Our field test center. The Shed. A dozen high-tech buildings nestled into the unforgiving mountainside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bloodshot and Harting enter from the helipad, they’re by the three members of CHAINSAW: mortally wounded soldie improved by Rising Spirit tech. Just like Bloodshot.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Marcus Tibbs is our team leader, counter intelligence expert, and sniper. LT. MARCUS TIBBS (African-American, 30s) has a kind face covered in scars. Cybernetic eyes mark him as the sniper stopped Bloodshot’s escape.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Sorry ‘bout that head shot.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Just glad you missed my face.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Wasn’t aiming for your face. Off Tibbs’s intimidating look, FLASH TO:

dialogues.speaker: NORTH KOREA
dialogues.text: Tibbs’s cybernetic eye looks through his rifle’s scope -- he sees is vegetation. Jungle sounds fade... replaced by ROAR of a JEEP.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A mortar explosion left Tibbs blind and deaf. With cochlear implants for hearing and ocular prosthetics for eyes... Tibbs’s eyes SNAP red -- revealing the DRIVER’S heat signature. He fires... the heat signature goes dark. BACK  31.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Tibbs never misses.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Don’t have to see you to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: SO LONG
dialogues.text: Wish I didn’t have to see Tibbs. Got a face like my nut sack. Out of his exoskeleton, So Long stands on next-gen prosth legs, partially obscured by his cargo shorts.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: You already met Corporal Harlin “So Long” Shifflet.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: So Long?

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: What we say to the bad guys when ass-bag here takes the field.

dialogues.speaker: SO LONG
dialogues.text: Ladies called me “So Long” way before I met this crew.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: After an IED took So Long’s legs, we built him a new pair... Off So Long’s “go-fuck-yourself” grin, FLASH TO:

dialogues.speaker: IRAQ
dialogues.text: So Long stomps through rubble in his exoskeleton.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Exoskeleton means there isn’t a cannon he can’t wield, making him our go-to for heavy artillery and urban assault. So Long fires his sound cannon. Iraqi GUNMEN flee, every orifice bleeding. BACK TO: So Long rubs his swollen jaw where Bloodshot nailed him w the stun baton during his failed escape...

dialogues.speaker: SO LONG
dialogues.text: Still owe ya for that cheap shot, Snow White.  32.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Know what’s intimidating? Your knowledge of Disney princesses. Before So Long can respond, a striking Indian woman with sleek air filters mounted on a neck brace intercedes.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t mind So Long -- his assertions of male dominance are just attempts to compensate for phallic deficiency. Harting nods towards the woman... she’s the one who threw sarin gas grenade during Bloodshot’s failed escape.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Warrant Officer Kareena “KP” Pillai is an expert in chemical weapons and psychological warfare. Off KP’s enigmatic gaze, FLASH TO:

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIA
dialogues.text: KP enters a crack house with just a thermos. TWEAKERS see defenceless beauty and move in for the kill...

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Her trachea was severed by a stray bullet in Afghanistan so now she breathes through a clavicle mounted respirator. KP opens the thermos -- gas escapes -- bad guys foam at t mouth and spontaneously shit their shorts. BACK TO:

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: As a result she’s immune to inhalants.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Only thing more dangerous than KP’s knowledge of biological weapons is her lack of social grace.

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: After you suffer a neck injury it’s hard to suffer fools. So Long glares at Bloodshot... doesn’t like the idea of b upstaged by Harting’s latest break-through.

dialogues.speaker: SO LONG
dialogues.text: So what do we call the noob... “B.S."? He looks to his teammates for a laugh -- doesn't get one.  33.

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: Did I say fools? I meant, “fool.” Bloodshot takes in the Chainsaw crew... his new “family.”

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Wounded warriors. I get it.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: No longer wounded. Enhanced. Improved. And most of all, given purpose. This is why they’re here. Same with you.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Welcome to the freak show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot faces off against Harting, on opposite ends of outdoor dojo. Chest-high metal rods like half-built columns punctuate t space between Bloodshot and Harting in a spread-out grid. Harting draws a SAMURAI SWORD from its scabbard, wielding with his prosthetic arm.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: For this exercise, you must disarm me.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: You made a pun there.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Take the sword from my hand. Harting gets into a defensive stance. Watchful.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: One question, doc. Will any of this training help get my memory back?

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Your memory? I don’t know. It’s possible. With enough stimulation, the nanites --

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: (I got my answer) Whatever, let’s do this. Bloodshot advances, quick on his feet... For a few moments the two dance, lunging and dodging...  34. But then Harting strikes, snake-swift, the blade SLICING Bloodshot in the leg. BLOODSHOT (CONT’D) Shit! Hang on, time out, I’m -- Harting stabs him AGAIN. Bloodshot falls over in mortal pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A windowless room with tumbling mats for a floor. Under fluorescent light, Bloodshot and KP square off. She a sleek metal QUARTER-STAFF but Bloodshot is empty-handed

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: So what are we doing now? Harting’s voice booms from the intercom overhead. And Bloodshot finds him watching from a plate glass window.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Try to reach the door behind KP. KP winks at Bloodshot.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: That one right there? KP pulls down a set of high-tech GOGGLES and then -- The lights go OUT. And it is crazy dark now. BLOODSHOT (CONT’D) Waitaminute -- But we can hear the WHOOSH-WHOOSH of the quarter-staff in motion and barely make out the silhouette of KP advancing KP’S POV In a green-ish world, she attacks Bloodshot, who’s trying get his bearings but then she sweeps his legs from under and he goes down HARD on the mat --

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hooded and bound Bloodshot rides next to Tibbs as they between the mountains.  35.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: World record is twenty-two minutes, believe it or not. That’s crazy, isn’t it? So you gotta make half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Half an hour doing what? Tibbs then PUSHES him out of the helicopter. Bloodshot FALLS thirty feet to certain death -- SLAMMING against the surface of a --

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Holding your breath! Hands bound, Bloodshot begins to sink... panic setting in

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Take control of your body -- adapt. Bloodshot flexes -- breaks the plastic cuffs -- swims for surface just as -- Tibbs spots him with his sniper rifle from the helicopter opens fire. Bloodshot panics -- can’t break the surface without taking a head shot.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What if this kills me?

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The nanites will signal us if you lose consciousness. We can revive you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Long stands at a charcoal grill where he’s heated up several rocks until they glow. Bloodshot stands opposite him, uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: SO LONG
dialogues.text: You’re gonna hold one of these in your hand until you can count to twenty. So Long pulls out a scalding hot rock with a pair of tong

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT SO LONG
dialogues.text: But that thing’s -- Hold out your hand.  36. Bloodshot reluctantly does so. So Long drops the stone in his hand -- and Bloodshot immediately DROPS the thing --

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Shit! So Long turns around to smirk at a watchful HARTING from elevated observation deck.

dialogues.speaker: SO LONG
dialogues.text: I woulda done it on the first try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot falls hard, clutching his leg. Instead of blood, a black fluid like tar, full of nanites spreads quickly.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: I nicked the femoral artery. Close the wound quickly. Focus. A normal man would die from this in twenty seconds. Bloodshot is breathing hard, panicking.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: I’m gonna die --

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: You don’t have to.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Oh my god you're a terrible doctor. His eyes start to roll up into his head, and the red circ on his chest begins to GLOW a warning, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot wakes up suddenly and reaches for his leg, to f he’s in a hospital room, hooked up to high-tech EKG gear. Harting stands at the door, arms crossed.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Try again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the KP test in darkness. She’s still whooping his before he can take two steps in any direction.  37.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: I can’t see a thing!

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then fix it so you can. Breathing hard, staying low, Bloodshot blinks -- ENDOSCOPIC SHOT: Inside his eye, just behind the lens, ro and cones reorganizing until the eye becomes more CAT-LIK and then -- BLOODSHOT’S POV Now he can see her. And the door. Everything has more of desaturated feel; grainy. But visible. BLOODSHOT MOVES -- and KP attacks -- but this time he’s r for her, parrying and dodging --

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: It’s working! And then a new overlay appears as Bloodshot fights KP: A tech TARGETING RETICULE, tracing KP’s movement, analyzing BLOODSHOT (CONT’D) This tech even has combat analytics. Bam! He gets a good counterattack on KP, turning the tide...

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: Don’t hate me for this. So KP then throws a chemical at his face and BLINDS HIM.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Oh COME ON! KP then attacks him again -- and Bloodshot falls HARD to floor with a THUD, arms splayed out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot sits up, waking suddenly, with the electrodes o his chest as his circular scar FADES. He gasps for air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot’s below the surface... he exhales... focusing. But then he starts to panic, old survival instincts screa that he can’t be doing what he’s doing, and GLUB-GLUB --  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot sits up, waking suddenly, in a coughing fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot’s clenched hand trembles as smoke curls up from molten ROCK he’s holding, hissing through his teeth:

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Nineteen... twenty! He drops the thing right away and stares at his hand -- The badly burned flesh instantly REPAIRS, softly shushing sizzling flesh until he’s back to normal. Bloodshot look up, triumphant, until he sees So Long comi at him with something new -- A blowtorch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot wakes again, with the same EKG electrodes on hi chest. He checks his skin for burns. Just pale flesh inst

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights clack back on, but the chemical toxins KP thre Bloodshot still have him blinded. KP attacks, demanding:

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: Adapt again! Come on! Bloodshot strains his ears again -- ENDOSCOPIC SHOT: Inside the eardrum, the space begins to reform, allowing him to hear every minute sound -- KP’S STAFF comes sailing down to strike him in the head b then Bloodshot CATCHES the blow with his palms and in two swift twists he DISARMS her of the weapon. Standing triumphant, Bloodshot raises his arms.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Adapted! I don’t need eyes to know I look good right now.  39. KP can’t help but grin at Bloodshot’s sudden snark, especially when she pulls a swift KICK TO HIS NUTS -- Bloodshot immediately collapses in a heap on the floor, wheezing in pain.

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: You still have weak spots. Remember that. Trick isn’t that you’re invincible. It’s that you can get back up. KP crouches down by Bloodshot, listening to him breathe through his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: KP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s just pain.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Easy for you to say --

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: Control the blood flow, the muscle group around that whole area. Trust me, I’m doing you a favor. Bloodshot starts to get up again but not before looking bewildered at KP:

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: Later on you’1ll realize this level of control has... other uses. She means sex, Bloodshot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot now has to deal with SPINNING BLADES that pop o of the grid of metal poles. As he moves for Harting, he’s SLICED across one bicep. He grunts, grits his teeth... and the wound SEALS UP. Two more spinning blades CUT into him as he weaves for Harting, and both times he breathes through his mouth and cuts self-repair. Then Harting STRIKES, but Bloodshot DODGES, and Harting’s is so strong, the sword cuts right through a metal rod. B One less spinning blade for Bloodshot to worry about. Harting strikes again, an overhead blow this time --  40. Bloodshot CLAPS his hands together, CATCHING the blade -- But not quite as elegantly as he’d like. Black blood drip down his arm. Grabbing the blade with both hands, his palms getting bad sliced, he wrenches the sword from Harting. It clatters to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Congrats. What you’ve become, what we've done this last week... it’s remarkable. Bloodshot clasps hands with Harting, congratulating... an then Harting plunges a SEPPUKU KNIFE into Bloodshot’s gut

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Sonofabitch, doc-- Bloodshot is suddenly on his knees. In shock at seeing th hilt sticking out of his abdomen.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: The ancient samurai were mentally prepared for death. Trained for it. Your training must surpass that. I have given you a mortal wound. If you get one out there in the world, and you don’t heal yourself, then it’s lights out. Because we won’t be there to revive you. Bloodshot grimaces. Bleeding out on the rocks. He notices skin starts to turn GRAY as it does. And then, through his shirt -- a brief PULSE OF RED LIGHT the shape of a circle. Exactly where his chest scar is.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: What... was that...

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: An alert system hardwired into the nanites, when you’re starting to lose too much of them. When you’re about to die. Unless you do something, right now. Your body has the power but your mind has doubt. Leap of faith time. Step off that ledge.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: I... can’t... FLASH ON: Aussie... smiling. That smug bastard. Is this a sign Bloodshot is getting some memory back? BACK TO:  41.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Then I’m sorry. For both of us. If you can’t do this, I'd rather you die here, at Rising Spirit, than out there, losing any chance I might have to study your remains. Bloodshot pulls out the sword and lets it clatter on the rocks beneath him.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Two... things... Bloodshot contorts in pain -- then rises to his knees. BLOODSHOT (CONT’D) First... that hurt. A lot. He slowly stands... the gut-wound closing before our eyes BLOODSHOT (CONT’D) Second... we made a deal. I survive your stress tests, you help me keep my promise: find that Aussie prick and end him. Harting can’t help but smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot stares intently. Rubbing his chin. REVERSE to reveal the object of his attention: A fully- stocked VENDING MACHINE. Chips, snacks, candy, energy dri Bloodshot puts in a full twenty dollars. And starts press buttons. KP enters, carrying something under one arm. A box.

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Hey yourself.

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: Just wanted to check in, see how you are. Bloodshot pulls a bag of nacho cheese tortilla chips from vending machine. Opens it. Tries one. As he does:

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Well, I lived through Harting’s whole samurai speech, so I got that going for me.  42. Bloodshot shrugs at the nacho cheese chip. Sets the bag a and presses another button. This time it’s peanut butter crackers. He tries one.

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: Yeah, he can be melodramatic. But it’s because he’s a man of principle and-- what are you doing? Bloodshot is now sampling cookies. He likes these.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Figuring out what I like. These -- (holds up chips) -- are an abomination. But these -- (holds up cookies) -- I could eat a hundred, right now.

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: You want to, but when you do, you immediately regret it. Trust me. (then) You really don’t remember anything? Bloodshot gets a far-off look in his eye, smiling sadly.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: I remember Gina... She’s the only mirror I have to my life. You know? I don’t know the things I did, but I know her smile. (beat) So either she was way out of my league and I got lucky, or I was a goddamn saint.

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: Well. I ever find a guy, and his memory gets wiped but he still remembers me, I'd say I’m the lucky one. It’s a loaded moment... a bond forming between these two. Mutual respect, maybe a little envy from KP. That’s when she offers him the box tucked under her arm.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: The Navy shipped you out with your personal effects, I guess to make it cleaner for them. Maybe... maybe something will jog your memory. Just don’t tell anyone I gave this to you.  43. Bloodshot takes the box like it’s the Crown Jewels. INT. BLOODSHOT’S BUNK ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Bloodshot stares at the box, then opens it. Inside: A broken wrist watch. A wallet that’s been gutted except for a few discount cards, and... An iPod. Bloodshot tries to power it up -- it’s dead. But he finds a charger under a shirt.

dialogues.speaker: ONE MINUTE LATER
dialogues.text: The device boots up and he can access it. The first app t jumps out at him is “Music.” Already queued on the playlist is some classic Def Leppar The cow bell sounds tinny on the little speaker.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: “It’s better to burn out, than to fade away.” How could I ever forget you guys? He pauses the music and closes the app. That’s when he sees the Photos feature. Clicks on it. In the Camera Roll: PHOTOS OF GINA. Candid moments of her dressed for a night out wit him -- posed as if she’s asking, “How do I look?” He thumbs through the pics, none of them really featuring much in the way of scenery beyond Gina on vacation with h Then one image, Gina running her hand through her hair --

dialogues.speaker: QUICK POP
dialogues.text: Suddenly Bloodshot is in that very moment, right then, watching Gina run her hand through her hair, smiling coyl

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Bloodshot trembles at the vivid moment. He nearly looks around the room as if he can suddenly smell her perfume.. But he is all alone. And his shoulders slump. His HAND grips the bunk, and he starts to WARP THE METAL a sorrow coming out as rage. But the groan of metal turns

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE ROAR of a helicopter on arrival to Rising Spirit.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INDIVIDUAL FACES flickering by -- thirty per second --

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Encrypted hard-line access to the CIA/Interpol shared database.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot watches the headshots on a view screen, Tibbs a Harting behind him.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Every driver's licence, passport, and mugshot ever taken. Three billion some-odd folks...

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Facebook for feds. Thousands of images reflect off Bloodshot’s dark eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If that Aussie is the needle, this is your haystack.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: I’m running a diagnostic on your nanites’ bioelectrical system, so you may experience some weird lapses... Bloodshot doesn’t respond. Tibbs SNAPS his fingers in fro of Bloodshot: doesn’t even blink.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s already gone. BLOODSHOT’S POV: Time slows to a crawl, each face holding screen for a beat. Bloodshot takes it all in. Waiting for a FLASH OF:

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE
dialogues.text: Thanks for the advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is deserted. Bloodshot is alone. Hasn’t moved - hasn't blinked -- in hours. His vigil of vengeance. Suddenly Bloodshot’s face begins to twitch, like a contortionist who can no longer hold his pose. Sweat beads on his brow... finally he reaches up, pauses images dancing by. ON SCREEN: one face. Familiar. Australian. This is his guy. The man who shot Gina in front of him. And now we have a name, glowing at us under the profile p

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Martin Axe. Found you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Long and Harting argue in front of an array of high-te networked computers, unaware that the mugshots of bad guy have finally stopped on Martin Axe.

dialogues.speaker: SO LONG
dialogues.text: I just don’t get it. You could pump me full of nanites instead of him. Why bother with Mister Broken Heart at all?

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: You're right. You don’t get it. It isn’t skill or training that makes him perfect, it’s what drives him.

dialogues.speaker: SO LONG
dialogues.text: Technology.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: You know the myth of Tantalus? Cursed for the rest of his days to be surrounded by fruit and water that recedes every time he reaches for it? That’s Bloodshot. He’s ever reaching for what he can’t have. (beat) It’s his prison.

dialogues.speaker: SO LONG
dialogues.text: I‘1l take his prison over mine any day. More data on Axe starts to fill screens. Files opened. Surveillance photography. It’s the digital version of dum a trash bin full of personal records.  46. The computer system CHIMES with an alert, finally attract Harting’s attention. He looks over at all the search data clearly culled by Bloodshot. SO LONG (CONT’D) Martin Axe? Who's this? ON ONE SCREEN: “Last known location: ST. PETERSBURG.” Bloodshot barrels into the room, surprising the men.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: I need to get to Russia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot gets a a fake passport from Tibbs.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Given US tensions with Putin, we can’t risk an incident on Russian soil. That means you're gonna be on your own -- no insertion, no back-up, no exfil. Tibbs notices Bloodshot checking the sights and thumbing safety on a Desert Eagle.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can’t take that on the plane, you know.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Considering my own blood will probably trip the metal scanner, I'll have to get creative with my travel. The rest of Chainsaw hangs back, saying “goodbye” without saying it. Bloodshot takes a deep breath... is he nervous

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: Think you’re ready? Few days ago you were a corpse.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Says the woman with the broken neck. KP and Bloodshot share a look... is she worried about him BLOODSHOT (CONT’D) I’1l be fine... survived the freakshow, didn’t I?  47.

dialogues.speaker: SO LONG
dialogues.text: We pulled our punches. Last time you saw this Axe clown, guy put a bullet in your brain...

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: I intend to return the favor.

dialogues.speaker: SO LONG
dialogues.text: (taunting) Killing him isn’t gonna bring your wife back.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Being a dick isn’t gonna bring your balls back. So Long’s on his feet -- Bloodshot holds his ground.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Calm down, ladies -- you’re both pretty. Bloodshot notices his pale skin.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: I kinda look like I sleep in a coffin.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Don’t like what you see? Change it.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Ha ha. Wait, really?

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: (samurai wisdom) The body is but an extension of the mind. Bloodshot considers this. He closes his eyes and exhales. MICROSCOPIC SHOT: Bloodshot’s skin cells -- one by one th transform from deathly pale to a robust flesh tone -- PULL OUT: the transformation SPREADS like a wave -- conti PULLING OUT to reveal: Bloodshot... his complexion healthy and vibrant. KP smiles. He's definitely ready. HARTING (PRE-LAP) (CONT’D) You'll brief us every six hours...  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harting leads Bloodshot to the front door. Bloodshot look startlingly normal, like he was when we first saw him.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Nanites use voice over IP so just ask for a connection. There’s a beat of silence... this is it. Bloodshot’s leav

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: I appreciate you letting me do this. I would’ve felt a pang of guilt if I had to escape instead.

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: This is a test, for both of us. But as I’ve said, there comes a time when you have to step off the ledge. (then) I’m a dead man if you don’t come back.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Being dead isn’t so bad. (then) I’1l come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a man-made island, giant commercial planes are literal coming in just a hundred feet over hotels and condos to l Out on the tarmac, a herd of PASSENGERS board a 747 while BAGGAGE HANDLERS load the freight compartment. Lingering on the line of Passengers as they ascend the stairs... No sign of Bloodshot here...

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You’ve given me a second chance -- a chance to make things right. But then an ASIAN BAGGAGE HANDLER climbs into the freight compartment with a box marked “fragile.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Handler sets the box down, walling off a section of t compartment. The Handler then sits behind that wall of baggage, takes off his ear protectors... And stares at his hands. He begins SHAKING HIS HEAD like has water in his ear or something, but then his FACE CHAN  49. MICROSCOPIC SEQUENCE: The brown eyes around his pupils sh to a different color, the skin tone shifts, and then-- It’s BLOODSHOT sitting in the freight compartment. He che himself in the reflective surface of a chrome support bea

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Damn. I looked good as an Asian dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 747 vaults into the stratosphere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodshot has three different suitcases open, pulling out potential clothing options and placing them against his c to see if they’d fit. All the while he’s singing to himse

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: If you think I’1l sit around while you chip away my brain / Listen I ain’t foolin’ and you'd better think again -- He finds a turtleneck that looks like a good fit and toss it into a Tumi briefcase he’s gutted to claim his own. A bag of homemade COOKIES sits in his lap, pulled from someone's checked luggage. Bloodshot looks up at nothing particular and says: BLOODSHOT (CONT’D) Open new window. Access employee roster for Halcyon Technologies. He takes a bite of a cookie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the MUSIC OF JUDAS PRIEST is blasting in his hea and we're looking at a slew of holographic website data floating in front of us, a dozen windows multitasking.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS PRIEST
dialogues.text: (music video window) If you think I’1l let it go you’re mad, you've got another thing comin’. One website pulls up a set of EMPLOYEE RECORDS for a tech company while other pages show satellite PHOTOS of a corporate compound in St. Petersburg. It’s an old buildin with rows of very expensive cars out front. The employee records page SCROLLS as if by mental command  50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same EMPLOYEE RECORDS show on the screens here at RST They're seeing all of Bloodshot’s inquiries real-time. Also, they’re victim to his music selection. KP sits with Harting in the center, watching the data go like a pair of voyeurs.

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: Is that Judas Priest?

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: (sigh) Yes. He’s using our Internet server link as his personal jukebox. KP leans in, increasingly fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: He used Axe’s income return forms to locate a Russian shell company Axe uses as cover. (sees another screen) Now he’s pulling up the building’s history. Is he looking for a point of access?

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: He can’t just walk in and ask to murder a high-tech arms dealer. So, I'd say yes. On the screens, faces of different RUSSIAN MEN AND WOMEN by, with employee ID numbers.

dialogues.speaker: KP
dialogues.text: So what’s he doing with that employee roster?

dialogues.speaker: HARTING
dialogues.text: Probably figuring out how many are working the night shift. THE SCREENS switch to a new video website with the title “Language Learners.” The first video: “Learning Russian. Lesson one.” The video plays at DOUBLE SPEED, all the while Judas Prie still WAILS their guitars, right into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 747 now parked at a gate.  51. BAGGAGE HANDLERS dressed for the cold weather unload the luggage from a conveyor belt as the bags travel from the belly of the plane. The Handlers turn around to grab another suitcase but ins find BLOODSHOT riding the conveyor down, dressed more war now himself, too, and carrying his (stolen) briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: (in Russian, subtitled) Luggage inspection. You handled that fragile box like it was your woman, good job. Here, have a cookie. Bloodshot leaves the mystified Handler with the cookie ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soaring above the northern capital of Russia, fourth larg city in Europe. Sun glistens off the snow-capped rooftops Street level. ALEXI KRIEGER, parks his car. Groceries in hand, he enters the front door of his up-scale flat.

dialogues.speaker: KRIEGER
dialogues.text: Viktor! INT. KRIEGER’S FLAT - DAY Silence. Krieger grabs a box of dog treats from his bag. heads into the kitchen and finds --

dialogues.speaker: KRIEGER
dialogues.text: Viktor. His DOBERMAN. Krieger shakes the box... but the dog could care less... he’s chomping on something else.

dialogues.speaker: KRIEGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Russian, subtitled) What you got there? Krieger moves closer -- sees that the dog is eating a ste Suddenly -- phone cord goes around Krieger's neck -- Bloodshot pulls it tight -- Krieger struggles --

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: If I wanted you dead, you’d be dead. Krieger gasps for air --  52. BLOODSHOT (CONT’D) Alexi Krieger. Yeah, I know who you are. You got an attack dog like Viktor for protection because you're not a fighter. So listen t--OOOF! Krieger’s ELBOW jams right in Bloodshot’s gut -- Then Krieger STOMPS Bloodshot’s foot -- Bloodshot loses his grip on the cord for a moment, and so Krieger LUNGES for the knife block -- Bloodshot PULLS back -- too late -- Krieger GRABS a blade LAUNCHES himself backwards -- SLAMS Bloodshot into the fridge -- again -- and again -- Doberman just watches -- that steak is really good. WHAM -- Bloodshot loses his grip on the cord. Krieger spi around -- STABS at Bloodshot -- the blade goes through Bloodshot’s hand -- BLOODSHOT (CONT’D) Seriously?! What’s the dog for?! Krieger sees he has the upper hand now, with Bloodshot impaled next to his fridge.

dialogues.speaker: KRIEGER
dialogues.text: Disposing of bodies. I will carve you up now.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Here’s your knife back. Bloodshot PUSHES his impaled hand further down the knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stunned Krieger watches as Bloodshot’s black blood heal the wound around the blade -- GRIPPING it so he can pull weapon out of a Krieger's hand.

dialogues.speaker: KRIEGER
dialogues.text: My god... Bloodshot headbutts the Russian -- BLACKNESS. EXT. KRIEGER’S FLAT - NIGHT Krieger wakes with a start, tied to a chair. Tied with various extension cords. It’s a weird mix of different household items around the chair, including a curling iro  53.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: Couldn't find any rope or tape so I had to make do. By the way -- curling iron?

dialogues.speaker: KRIEGER
dialogues.text: Ex-girlfriend left it. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: I’m not up for discussion. Martin Axe is. You worked with him up until last month when you were let go. You worked in R&D. You know what he’s doing here. And what I can expect if I come at him. Krieger keeps staring at Bloodshot’s hand. His perfectly healed hand, as if he’d never been stabbed.

dialogues.speaker: KRIEGER
dialogues.text: Your blood... it’s been replaced? Micro- robotic proteins, yes? I hear rumors... never believed them. But you healed, yes?

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: I know a few parlor tricks. So, Martin Axe. What did you do for him? Let’s start there.

dialogues.speaker: KRIEGER
dialogues.text: Will tell you everything. But for a price... your blood. A sample. Bloodshot considers the proposition...

dialogues.speaker: KRIEGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All you want to know... why Axe is here, how you can get to him. Bloodshot gets a shot glass from the bar, grabs a knife. Krieger hesitates... is Bloodshot going use it on Krieger Bloodshot puts his own hand over the glass -- grits his t and -- holy shit -- cuts off his own finger.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: (through the pain) Talk. Black blood runs into the shot glass...

dialogues.speaker: KRIEGER
dialogues.text: An EMP bomb. That’s what he hired me to build for him.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: What for? He robbing a casino?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this -- big enough to shut down entire city. He hired me to build it --

dialogues.speaker: BLOODSHOT
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: KRIEGER
